head.supplied: Sunday 5/7/96 ¶ ¶ As this is a favorable season for moisture, dear Mr Williamson, I would like to ask, whether you could easily procure 100 flowering and 100 fruiting specimens of Mitrasacme distylis...

div.p: Box 1791/15, Williamson Papers, La Trobe Australian Collection, State Library of Victoria, Melbourne.

As this is a favorable season for moisture, dear Mr Williamson, I would like to ask, whether you could easily procure 100 flowering and 100 fruiting specimens of Mitrasacme distylis and perhaps also of the very rare Leeuwenhookia
Leeuvenhookia? See M to H. Williamson, 20 September 1894, n. 1. Sonderi. In France I have started an international collection of rare plants (in dried specimens),
For the proposal to establish the 'publication' of collections of exsiccatae, under the auspices of the International Academy of Botanical Geography (Académie Internationale de Géographie Botanique), see B93.11.02. and if you could contribute to the sets, for which the Subscribers are there secured these tiny plants, your honored name as the Gatherer would be put on the printed labels. As these little things are so easily dried and gathered, you might even get still more specimens of them, avoiding however the risk of annihilating them in any locality there.
